title-group.article-title: A Review of Diabetes Mellitus–Specific Family Assessment Instruments

article-meta.aff: 1University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing, Philadelphia

author-notes.corresp: MinKyoung Song, University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing, 418 Curie Boulevard, Philadelphia, PA 19104-4217. Email: mksong80@gmail.com

abstract.p: Family dynamics and attributes are increasingly recognized as affecting management of diabetes mellitus (DM); however, little research has been done on the validity and usefulness of family assessment instruments (FAIs). This article reviewed the literature that employs DM-specific FAIs and evaluates whether the instruments comprehensively captured family attributes/processes and were robust enough to be useful in understanding the relationship between family attributes/issues and DM-related health care. Studies using eight instruments were identified through a search of literature published from 1982 to 2010 and were analyzed with criteria derived from the measurement and family literatures. The findings of this study revealed that DM-specific FAIs yield useful data about family-related phenomenon; however, some domains of DM-specific care, such as family dynamics/functioning, were not overtly measured. Suggestions for improving DM-specific FAIs are provided and a rationale for why DM-specific and non-DM-specific FAIs is needed to fully measure family issues related to family dynamics/attributes on DM patient care.

body.p: Social context is increasingly acknowledged as a significant influence on how effectively individuals manage chronic illness (Haire-Joshu, 1996; Tang, Brown, Funnell, & Anderson, 2008; Wallhagen, 1999). Within that broader framework, family context is considered a primary factor affecting management of chronic conditions (Rolland & Williams, 2005). Thus, it is important for diabetes mellitus (DM) health care providers and researchers to expand their knowledge of how to integrate assessment of patients’ families into DM-related clinical practice. To assess families appropriately, available family assessment instruments (FAIs) must be examined for their usefulness and scientific adequacy.

sec.title: Types of FAIs
sec.p: Traditionally, DM health care providers and researchers have used two types of FAIs: (a) non-disease-specific (known as noncategorical) instruments (e.g., the family management measure and the family assessment device) and (b) disease-specific (known as categorical) instruments (e.g., Diabetes Family Behavior Checklist [DFBC]). Non-disease-specific FAIs examine variables of family context or generic dimensions of families’ experiences not related to any specific disease, whereas disease-specific FAIs examine idiosyncratic characteristics of families’ experiences related to a specific chronic disease (Knapp & Harris, 1998; Thompson & Gustafson, 1996).

Although both types of measurement instruments are useful in DM clinical practice and research, studies are needed to understand more fully the respective advantages and disadvantages of each type of instrument and to suggest criteria for determining their appropriateness for a particular study or clinical practice. Questions arise as to whether (a) non-disease-specific instruments are sensitive enough to capture important family context as it relates to families’ experiences with specific diseases and (b) disease-specific instruments might not capture important variables of family context that are not obviously tied to disease-specific experiences but nonetheless affect patients/families experiences of managing chronic disease.

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: As a first step toward the ultimate goal of developing greater understanding of the advantages and disadvantages of both types of FAIs, in this article, we (a) reviewed the literature and research on the use of DM-specific FAIs, (b) evaluated whether they comprehensively captured family attributes/issues (e.g., family conflict or support), and (c) evaluated whether or to what degree they were useful in understanding the relationship between family attributes or issues and DM-related health care. A logical next step would be for researchers to conduct a similar evaluation of the literature on the application of non-disease-specific FAIs to DM care. We expect the results of this review to yield important insight for researchers understanding about disease-specific instruments.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The literature related to family assessments from 1982 to 2010 was reviewed through a computerized search of the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Health and Psychosocial Instruments (HAPI), and Medline. The keywords used for the search strategy included diabetes/diabetic and family/families. Initially, 87 articles were obtained from the reference lists. Duplicates were removed and titles and abstracts were reviewed, resulting in the identification of eight DM-specific FAIs discussed in the literature.

To comprehensively evaluate the characteristics and usefulness of each of the selected instruments, we synthesized an analytical matrix developed by Neabel, Fothergill-Bourbonnais, and Dunning (2000) specific to instruments with pertinent aspects of Feetham and Meister’s (1999) specific to family research. The authors of the present review considered the evaluative criteria used in Neabel et al.’s matrix practical and useful, comprising theoretical basis, purpose; description; unit of interest; ease of administration and scoring; reading level; psychometric evaluation; and utility to guide clinical practice and research. In addition, Feetham’s and Meister’s criteria were employed to underscore the importance of defining family when measuring of family phenomenon and comparing the consistency of such definitions when synthesizing a group of studies. Finally, we evaluated how many times each instrument was used.

The following measurement instruments were identified from the literature and are summarized in Table 1: Diabetes Family Conflict Scale (DFCS; Hood, Butler, Anderson, & Laffel, 2007), Diabetes Family Responsibility Questionnaire (DFRQ; Anderson, Auslander, Jung, Miller, & Santiago, 1990), Family Summary of Diabetes Self-Care Activities Survey (FSDCA; Scollan-Koliopoulos, O’Connell, & Walker, 2007a), DFBC (Schafer, McCaul, & Glasgow, 1986), DFBC-II (Glasgow & Toobert, 1988), Diabetes Family Behavior Scale (DFBS; McKelvey et al., 1993), Family Illness Perception Questionnaire (IPQ)–diabetes version (Scollan-Koliopoulos, O’Connell, & Walker, 2006), and Diabetes Social Support Questionnaire (DSSQ)–family version (La Greca & Bearman, 2002). In the following section, the eight family assessment measurement instruments were analyzed according to nine criteria.

sec.title: Theoretical Bases
sec.p: Four of the eight instruments were based on specific theoretical frameworks. No explicit theoretical bases were found for DFCS, DFRQ, DFBS, and DSSQ-family version.

“Social-learning theory” was the underlying framework for DFBC and DFBC-II. Social-learning theory is based on the concept that human behavior is influenced by a reciprocal interaction between the individual and their environment (Bandura, 1977), and it views the family as an influencing factor (supportive or nonsupportive) on self-care behaviors of a patient with DM (Glasgow & Toobert, 1988; Schafer, Glasgow, McCaul, & Dreher, 1983).

The FSDCA is based on the “situation-specific theory,” a theory that in turn is based on three main elements: (a) themes of interaction with patients in clinical practice, (b) the Rolland’s Family-Systems-Illness and Disability Framework (Rolland, 1994; Rolland & Williams, 2005), and (c) “social-learning theory” (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a; described above). Situation-specific theory is clinically specific and reflects the social and historical contexts of the patients with DM in the study (Im & Meleis, 1999).

The Family IPQ-diabetes version is based on “illness perception” (derived from “Self-Regulation Theory”)—a concept used to describe how perceptions or their beliefs about DM affect patients with DM and their family members (Leventhal, Leventhal, & Cameron, 2001; Scollan-Koliopoulos, O’Connell, & Walker, 2007b). As an example, the term can be used to describe the preconceptions about DM that a recently diagnosed patient with DM might have if they had a family member who was previously diagnosed with the disease (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007b).

However, despite the identification of theoretical frameworks for some of the studies that use FAIs, definitions of the concepts that researchers were attempting to measure were not consistently and clearly provided. Ganong (2003) reported that many researchers often do not clearly describe the concepts that they are attempting to assess. This lack of clear definitions may lead to difficulty in assessing the validity of FAIs. Theory application and concept clarification will be important factors for future researchers to consider as they revise current family instruments or develop new instruments.

sec.title: Purpose and Content
sec.p: All the FAIs in this analysis (Anderson et al., 1990; Glasgow & Toobert, 1988; Hood et al., 2007; La Greca & Bearman, 2002; McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993; Schafer et al., 1986; Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a) measure self-care activities such as diet, exercise, glucose testing, and medication (insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents). Specifically, four instruments (DFBC, DFBC-II, DFBS, and DSSQ-family version) focus on perceived family support on performing self-care activities for an individual with DM and/or their family members. Two instruments (FSDCA and DSSQ-family version) examine the perceptions of DM patients’ family members regarding DM self-care behaviors. The Family IPQ-diabetes version examines illness representation of family members of patients with DM and their perceptions regarding DM complications. The DFCS assesses the level of DM-specific conflict in performing self-care among families with children and adolescents with type 1 DM (Hood et al., 2007; Rubin, Young-Hyman, & Peyrot, 1989). The DFRQ assesses individual family members’ perceptions of who takes responsibility for a broad range of tasks involved in managing a child/adolescent’s DM (Anderson et al., 1990).

In addition to self-care behaviors, various instruments also measure other components of DM care. The DFCS examines the knowledge of updated language of DM management of family members of patients with DM, their awareness of DM technology (e.g., logging blood glucose results), and the amount they discuss of DM with relatives, friends, and so on (Hood et al., 2007). The DFBS measures overall DM management, such as communication with health care providers and obtaining DM supplies (McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993). The Family IPQ-diabetes version divides its data into five domains of family perceptions related to the timeline of DM, the general consequences of having DM, the controllability of DM, how DM can be identified, and the social consequence of having DM (such as social stigmatization; Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2006).

sec.title: Description
sec.p: Instruments are structured as self-report questionnaires and self-report and/or family member(s)-reporting questionnaires. The length of the questionnaires vary, ranging from 9 questions in the FSDCA (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a) to 47 questions in the DFBS (McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993). A brief description of each instrument is provided in Table 1.

sec.title: Unit of Interest
sec.p: The unit of interest refers to which family members are the focus of a given assessment instrument (e.g., individual, dyad, family or household, or extended family) and can be categorized into two broad categories: predictor variable and criterion/consequence variable (Ganong, 2003). For example, if a researcher wanted to examine how family functioning was related to metabolic control in adolescents with type 2 DM, the study involves a family-level predictor and individual-level criterion and/or consequence. In this analysis, the units of interest vary from instrument to instrument. In the DFCS (Hood et al., 2007; Rubin et al., 1989) and the DFRQ (Anderson et al., 1990), the units of interest were either dyads (between children and parents) or family (if no family members exist other than an affected child and parents). These two measures had the implicit assumption that DM care is accomplished through shared family behaviors; thus, they did not differentiate between predictor and criterion variables and could be used for either. In the FSDCA (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a), the Family IPQ-diabetes version (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2006), and the DSSQ-family version (La Greca & Bearman, 2002), both predictor and criterion variables were at the individual level. In the DFBC (Schafer et al., 1986) and the DFBC-II (Glasgow & Toobert, 1988), the predictor variable was at the individual, dyad, or family level, whereas the criterion variable was at the individual level. In the DFBS (McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993), the predictor variable was at the family level, whereas the criterion variable was at the individual level.

In addition, unit of interest can be categorized by target population. DFRQ (Anderson et al., 1990) targets families with children who have Type 1 DM; DFCS (Hood et al., 2007; Rubin et al., 1989), DFBC (Schafer et al., 1986), and DFBS (McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993) target families with children and/or adolescents who have Type 1 DM; DSSQ-family version (La Greca & Bearman, 2002) targets families with adolescents who have Type 1 DM; DFBC-II (Glasgow & Toobert, 1988) and the Family IPQ-diabetes version (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2006) target families with adults who have Type 2 DM; and FSDCA (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a) targets adults with Type 2 DM who have a family history of DM.

sec.title: Ease of Administration and Scoring
sec.p: Ease of administration and scoring is an important factor for health care providers and researchers to consider because it may affect response rates and thus, indirectly, affect reliability and validity. The manual and all items for each instrument were reported in the original articles (DFCS, DFRQ, FSDCA, DFBC, DFBS, Family IPQ-diabetes version, and DSSQ-family version) except for the DFBC-II. The amount of time needed to complete the DFRQ, FSDCA, DFBC, DFBC-II, DFBS, Family IPQ-diabetes version, and DSSQ-family version was not reported. It was reported that the DFCS questionnaire could be completed within 5 min for all 19 items (Hood et al., 2007).

In general, no difficulties in scoring are noted with the DFCS, DFRQ, DFBC, DFBC-II, and DSSQ-family version. There were some concerns noted by Scollan-Koliopoulos et al. regarding the accurateness of the respondents’ recollections and how to treat missing data with the FSDCA (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a) and the Family IPQ-diabetes version (Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2006). Most instruments were scored in the reported research as the same as they were originally developed in each study although some researchers have used only a part of the original questionnaires. For example, Anderson, Brackett, Ho, and Laffel (1999) used the DFBC measure (Schafer et al., 1986) in their study; however, they only used the subscale measuring unsupportive behavior and omitted two items considered outdated.

sec.title: Reading Level
sec.p: Because some individuals and family members might have limited reading skills and/or difficulties in understanding complex terminology, measurement instruments should be written at a sixth-grade level (Dillman, 2007; Doak, Doak, & Root, 1996; Weiss & Coyne, 1997). The Family IPQ-diabetes version, DFBC, and DFBC-II (Glasgow & Toobert, 1988; Schafer et al., 1986; Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2006) were all written on a sixth-grade reading level. The DFRQ was described as being appropriate for people at the age of 6 years and older (Anderson et al., 1990). The reading level was not reported for the updated and revised DFCS, FSDCA, DFBS, and DSSQ-family version (Hood et al., 2007; La Greca & Bearman, 2002; McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993; Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a).

sec.title: Psychometric Evaluation
sec.p: All the instruments reported acceptable internal consistency reliability (mostly Cronbach’s α more than .60), and only the DFBC, DFBC-II, and DFBS report stability, which was also appropriate. Each instrument was reported to have strong validity. Construct validity data are available for the DFCS, DFRQ, FSDCA, and the Family IPQ-diabetes version. Concurrent validity data were available for the DFCS, DFRQ, and DSSQ-family version. Predictive validity data were available for the DFCS, DFBS, and DSSQ-family version. Finally, convergent validity data were available for the DFBC and DFBC-II. A detailed description of reliability and validity of each instrument was reported in Table 2.

caption.p: Review of Diabetes Mellitus (DM)-Specific Family Assessment Instruments: Reliability and Validity.

td.bold: Updated and Revised-Diabetes Family Conflict Scale (DFCS)

tr.td: Internal consistency: α = .85 for youth report of DM-specific conflict; α = .81 for caregiver report of DM-specific conflict.

Construct validity: Exploratory factor analysis revealed two factors (direct and indirect management tasks), and these two factors totaled 4.63, indicating a 24% explanation of the variance across all 19 items (4.63/19). Child and caregiver reports of DFCS total score showed a significant correlation (r = .26, p < .01).
Hood, Butler, Anderson, and Laffel (2007; Original: Rubin, Young-Hyman, and Peyrot, 1989)
The subscales: α = .75 for direct management tasks; α = .69 for indirect management tasks.

Concurrent validity: Youth-reported conflict correlated with negative affect around blood glucose monitoring (BGM; r = .35, p < .01) and poor quality of life (r = –.36, p < .01). Caregiver-reported conflict was correlated with the report of their own negative affect around BGM (r = .46, p < .01), their proxy report of poorer quality of life in the youths (r = –.35, p < .01), and greater perceived caregiver burden (r = .45, p < .01).

Predictive validity: Both child (r = .27, p < .01) and caregiver (r = .26, p < .01) report of DM-specific family conflict were correlated with hemoglobinA1c (HbA1c) values, indicating that higher levels of DM-specific conflict were associated with poorer glycemic control. Direct management tasks showed a slightly higher correlation with HbA1c than did indirect management tasks (r = .25 vs. r = .22).
Internal consistency: α = .85 (for the total DFRQ scale).

Construct validity: Factor analysis revealed that each of three factors (general health maintenance, regimen tasks, and social presentation of DM) explains total item variance of 39%, 11%, and 9%. Among these factors, low to moderate correlations were reported: general health and regimen tasks (r = .41, p < .001), general health and social presentation (r = .26, p < .001), and regimen tasks and social presentation (r = .21, p < .01).

td.xref: Anderson, Auslander, Jung, Miller, and Santiago (1990)

tr.td: Concurrent validity: Higher reports of independence for individual family members as measured by the Moos Family Environment Scale (FES) independence subscale were associated with mother’s reports of the child assuming greater responsibility for regimen tasks on the DFRQ (r = .27, p < .01) and for the total tasks of the DFRQ scale (r = .21, p < .05; Anderson et al., 1990).

td.bold: Family Summary of Diabetes Self-care Activities Survey (FSDCA)

tr.td: The reliability of all the combined dietary items for FSDCA was greater than .80.
Construct validity: Factor analysis was performed with five factors (diet, exercise, glucose monitoring, medication, and insulin adherence). The factors accounted for approximately 84% of variance.

Internal consistency: An average Cronbach’s α of .73 for the positive score for adults and their family members but only .43 for the negative score. The average Cronbach’s α of .63 for the positive scores for adolescents and their family members and .60 for the negative score.

Convergent validity: Both positive and negative scores for adults were related to their family members’ scores at each data collection period (r from .27 [p < .10] to .68 [p < .001]). Scores of adolescents and their family members were much less closely related (r from .01 to .27; all statistically nonsignificant).

Stability: 6-month test-retest interval: Correlations for adults and their family members ranged from .58 to .72 (all p < .01). Correlations for adolescents and their family members for the positive scores with r = .60 and .75 (p < .05) but were .60 and .28 for the negative scores.
2-month test-retest interval: Correlations for adults range from .84 to .69 for the positive and negative scores.
2-day test-retest interval: .95 and .77 for the positive and negative scores for adults.

Internal consistency: α = .71 for the positive summary score and α = .64 for the negative summary score (Wen, Shepherd, & Parchman, 2004). The subscales: it ranged from α = .09 (diet support) to α = .70 (glucose testing support), with a mean of α = .34 (Glasgow & Toobert, 1988).
Convergent validity: Overall positive and negative scores of the DFBC II showed reasonably good convergent validity (r = .53 and .56, respectively, both p < .01).

Stability: 6-month test-retest interval: Diet (r = .59) and exercise (r = .76) For other two scores (glucose testing and medication support) were less stable (r = .22 and .05; Glasgow & Toobert, 1988).

The subscales of the DFBC II specific to each of the four regimen areas assessed revealed good convergence between patient and family-member versions of the scale (r = .40-.56) with the exception of support for glucose testing (r = .02; Glasgow & Toobert, 1988).
Internal consistency: α = .86 for total score, α = .81 for guidance-control subscale (15 items), and α = .79 for warmth-caring subscale (15 items).
The DFBS failed to confirm construct validity because the researchers did not conduct factor analysis to validate the support items (Hanna, 2006).
McKelvey et al. (1989, 1993)
Test-retest reliability (3 weeks): Cronbach’s α for the warmth and caring, guidance and control, and problem-solving items were .79, .83, and .52, respectively (McKelvey et al., 1989).

Predictive validity: The DFBS total score was related to HbA1c (r = –.12, p < .03) and the guidance-control subscale was related to HbA1c (r = –.17, p < .002). However, the relationship between the warmth-caring subscale and HbA1c was not significant (r = –.06, p < .29).

Internal consistency: The subscales: social consequences (α = .84), controllability (α = .71) timeline, (α = .76), identity (α = .88), and general consequences (α = .55; Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2006).

Construct validity: The five-factor solution (identity, timeline, controllability, general consequences, social consequences) accounted for approximately 50% of variance and eigenvalues more than 1.00.
Internal consistency: Normative scoring approach: .95 for total, .75 for insulin, .85 for blood testing, .93 for meals, .85 for exercise, and .83 for emotions.

Concurrent validity: Adolescents who reported more frequent family support for DM care viewed their families as more supportive (perceived social support-family; r = .47, p < .001), and more cohesive (FES-cohesion; r = .34, p < .01; La Greca & Bearman, 2002).

Individualized approach: .98 for total, .82 for insulin, .91 for blood testing, .96 for meals, .89 for exercise, .89 for emotions. These two normative scores and individualized scores were significantly interrelated (r = .88, p < .001).

Predictive validity: The total individualized score predicted 6% additional variance (p < .025; La Greca & Bearman, 2002). For the individualized ratings: It predicted 17% additional unique variance in adolescents’ adherence (p < .01).

sec.p: Regarding additional reports on reliability and validity in addition to original articles, Drotar and Levers (1994) reported internal consistency ranging from an alpha of .83 to .92 on DFRQ. Chiu (2005) reported reliabilities for the DFBS total scale, reinforcement, modeling, and interaction patterns subscales as .74, .85, .73, and .73, respectively. Lewin et al. (2005) reported internal consistency of the DFBC for children ranging from an alpha of .74 to .79 and for parents ranging from an alpha of .71 to .74. In addition, this study reported moderate to strong convergent validity based on correlations with other measures (Lewin et al., 2005). Although most of the additional reported reliability and validity are similar to those of original articles, further studies are still needed to confirm these results because later studies only tested part of either original instruments or original questionnaires that are needed to be updated to include current DM research and clinical practice guidelines.

sec.title: Utility to Guide Clinical Practice and Research
sec.p: To be useful in practice, instruments measuring family phenomenon ideally need to be tested across various ethnic and cultural groups, in various family constellations and in various settings. The DFBC and DFBC-II were used with families of various race/ethnicities, including ethnic minority populations (Jayne & Rankin, 2001; Rankin, Galbraith, & Huang, 1997; Sabone, 2002), but the six other instruments (DFCS, DFRQ, FSDCA, DFBS, Family IPQ-diabetes version, and DSSQ-family version) have not been tested for use with ethnic minorities. There have not been reports on the use of any of the eight instruments with diverse family configurations (e.g., including single-parent families), and none of the eight instruments in this study provided information about normative data and/or responsiveness. This lack of data makes the analysis of the comparative usefulness of any particular instrument across diverse populations and across different family configurations difficult.

With some modifications, each of the instruments could be used to measure family attributes in different target populations. For example, the DFCS was designed to measure conflict in families with children who have type 1 DM, but it could easily be modified to measure conflict in families with adults who have type 1 DM, families with children/adolescents who have type 2 DM, and so on.

sec.title: The Number of Reported Uses
sec.p: The current number of reported uses of each instrument was reviewed through the CINAHL, HAPI, ISI Web of Science, and PubMed. Twelve studies used the DFCS. Twenty-seven studies used the DFRQ FAI, 23 used the DFBC, 6 used the DFBC II, and 14 used the DFBS. No studies were found that used the FSDCA, the Family IPQ-diabetes version, and the DSSQ-family version (outside the original studies). Detailed literature is summarized in Table 3. Table 3 provides detailed information on studies that used each instrument and whether these studies reported reliability and/or validity of the instrument(s).

sec.p: Out of the 71 total studies (excluding duplicated articles) that reported the uses of these instruments, 21 articles were published in DM-specific journals (e.g., Diabetes Care and Diabetes Educator). Only two articles were published in a family journal (Journal of Family Nursing and Families, Systems, & Health). Among the rest, 33 articles were published in pediatric/adolescent journals (e.g., Journal of Pediatric Nursing and Journal of Pediatric Psychology), 12 articles were published in general journals (e.g., Journal of Nursing Scholarship and Journal of Nursing Research), and 3 were doctoral dissertations.
Our review revealed that although existing DM-specific FAIs yield information that is useful for DM-related clinical practice and research, their usefulness has some important limitations.

Although they are all termed family measures, none of the instruments we reviewed collect data that allow for an explicit and precise theoretical and/or operational definition of “family.” Thus, they are all of limited usefulness to research and/or clinical practice where sociodemographic attributes of families are a relevant consideration. For example, these instruments would not allow for a researcher to examine what kinds of families are being studied (e.g. household, biological, functional, and blended). Nor would they be useful for clinicians or researchers who want to tailor their practice or research to families with specific characteristics or attributes related to family conflict and/or support.

Second, none of the instruments integrated a conceptual or operational concept of clinical practice with how they categorize data. For example, they provide information on the relative level of DM-related support in a given family, but there is no “normative data” (cutoff scores) that allow for precise categorization of the data, and there were no attempts in any of the instruments to integrate family support levels with clinical implications. Thus, if an instrument reveals that a particular family has a given level of family support, there is no accompanying conceptualization of the implications for clinical practice, that is, whether the given level of support would justify clinical intervention.

Third, none of the instruments measured clinically important differences over time (responsiveness). Because the instruments were not designed to measure variables over time, they are not optimally useful for clinicians to determine appropriate timing for clinical interventions. Both normative data and responsiveness are important criteria for evaluating the usefulness of measurement instruments in guiding clinical practice and research (Harris & Warren, 1995; Neabel et al., 2000).

Fourth, as discussed above, these instruments have not been tested across diverse groups or settings. Future studies are needed to validate these instruments in samples more representative of diverse populations of patients with DM.

Fifth, some of the instruments did not examine elements of DM care comprehensively. For example, the FSDCA did not include items on DM foot-care or smoking—both of which are crucial components of recommended DM care.

Finally, although each instrument effectively measures the family phenomena they intended to capture, some of the instruments only measure family phenomena from one perspective. For example, the Family IPQ-diabetes version measured the perceptions of family members about how adults in that family who have Type 2 DM view their own illness. However, these perceptions of family members were not compared with the perceptions of the adults who have DM about their own disease. Thus, it is not clear whether the family members’ perceptions are the same as the persons’ with DM. Including multiple perceptions, in other words the perception of the adult with DM along with the perceptions of the family members, would enhance the validity of the instrument.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Notwithstanding the limitations of the instruments we described above, our review found that the domain DM-specific FAIs yield data that can be useful for researchers and clinicians; these instruments do reveal valuable information related to (a patient/family member’s) perceived support for DM self-care activities and/or family conflict and responsibility related to DM care (Anderson et al., 1990; Glasgow & Toobert, 1988; Hood et al., 2007; La Greca & Bearman, 2002; McKelvey et al., 1989, 1993; Schafer et al., 1986; Scollan-Koliopoulos et al., 2007a). Thus, if a researcher or clinician is focusing on the influence of family support on DM care, the DM-specific assessment instruments we examined are appropriate and useful. However, we found that there are some domains of DM-specific care that were not analyzed in current existing instruments, such as family dynamics and/or functioning. It would be useful to develop additional DM-specific FAIs that focus on these other aspects of DM self-care or to include a separate measure of those concepts.

If additional DM-specific assessment instruments are developed, a larger question still needs to be addressed: What are the methodological advantages/disadvantages of using a DM-specific instrument versus a non-disease-specific instrument? Our conclusion is that it is heavily dependent on one’s research question and/or purpose that guides the determination of which type to use or if they should be combined to work synergistically. In theory, each type of instrument might be more appropriate for a specific context: DM-specific/categorical FAIs may identify family problems/issues more appropriately for informing DM clinical practice, and (because they are targeted more specifically and are, therefore, likely more sensitive to change) they may be more helpful for researchers who want to see changes in DM-related family conflict/behaviors through longitudinal design and/or intervention research. However, non-disease-specific FAIs may be regarded as appropriate for a holistic approach to treat chronic illnesses because individuals with various chronic medical conditions tend to have many similar disease-related life experiences and health care needs (Liu et al., 2005; Whyte, Baggaley, & Rutter, 1997).

The benefits of each type are not mutually exclusive to either patients with DM or people without chronic diseases/patients with other chronic diseases. Consistent with this line of reasoning, Stein and Jessop (1989) stated that a non-disease-specific approach to evaluate family problems/issues of patients with DM has the potential to help DM health care professionals benefit from lessons learned from clinical experiences with patients with other chronic diseases (e.g., cystic fibrosis). But the benefits of using non-disease-specific instruments could also influence the science in the opposite direction, whereby health care providers who work with patients and families experiencing varied conditions can gain insight from instruments that measure the experiences of patients with DM and their families (Knafl et al., 2009).

This review was the first step toward gaining a grasp on whether disease-specific or non-disease-specific instruments might be more or less useful, respectively, for certain kinds of studies related to chronic diseases. Before applying the results of this review to DM clinical practice and research, it would be helpful for health care providers and researchers to have more information about the advantages/disadvantages of both of these types of instruments. More in-depth reviews should be conducted to evaluate non-disease-specific FAIs, and comparison studies should be conducted to evaluate the relative effectiveness of each type of assessment instrument for different types of research questions and clinical practice objectives.
